page.title: 16A LOCAL HISTORIC RUIN
page.content: This building,North of Winchburgh,is complete to the wall head,but roofless.It compreses a main block of three storeys with tall square towers at each end.The upper floors are reached by tall stair-turrets. At one time this fine 16th century house was surrounded by elaborately planned gardens.Now these gardens are rough pastures for sheep and horses.It was at one time rather remote but with the advert of the M9 motorway,motorists now have a fine view of it. The Durhams of Duntarvie were once the hands here and presumably the builders,but by 1628 it was in the lairds of the Hamiltons,the Earls of Abercorn was confined here for religious non-conformity after a short spell in the Tolbooth Prison in Edinburgh.
